trans-unit.source: Browsing and managing storage resources with Server Explorer
trans-unit.target: Browsing and managing storage resources with Server Explorer

trans-unit.source: Browsing and managing storage resources with Server Explorer
trans-unit.target: Browsing and managing storage resources with Server Explorer

trans-unit.source: If you've installed the Azure Tools for Microsoft Visual Studio, you can view blob, queue, and table data from your storage accounts for Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you've installed the Azure Tools for Microsoft Visual Studio, you can view blob, queue, and table data from your storage accounts for Azure.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Storage node in Server Explorer shows data that’s in your local storage emulator account and your other Azure storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Storage node in Server Explorer shows data that’s in your local storage emulator account and your other Azure storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: To view Server Explorer in Visual Studio, on the menu bar, choose View, Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: To view Server Explorer in Visual Studio, on the menu bar, choose View, Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: The storage node shows all of the storage accounts that exist under each Azure subscription/certificate you're connected to.
trans-unit.target: The storage node shows all of the storage accounts that exist under each Azure subscription/certificate you're connected to.

trans-unit.source: If your storage account doesn't appear, you can add it by following the instructions <linkText>later in this topic</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If your storage account doesn't appear, you can add it by following the instructions <linkText>later in this topic</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Starting in Azure SDK 2.7, you can also use the new Cloud Explorer to view and manage your Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: Starting in Azure SDK 2.7, you can also use the new Cloud Explorer to view and manage your Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Managing Azure Resources with Cloud Explorer</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Managing Azure Resources with Cloud Explorer</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: Server Explorer automatically shows a list of blobs, queues, and tables in your storage emulator account.
trans-unit.target: Server Explorer automatically shows a list of blobs, queues, and tables in your storage emulator account.

trans-unit.source: The storage emulator account is listed in Server Explorer under the Storage node as the Development node.
trans-unit.target: The storage emulator account is listed in Server Explorer under the Storage node as the Development node.

trans-unit.source: To see the storage emulator account’s resources, expand the Development node.
trans-unit.target: To see the storage emulator account’s resources, expand the Development node.

trans-unit.source: If the storage emulator hasn’t been started when you expand the Development node, it will automatically start.
trans-unit.target: If the storage emulator hasn’t been started when you expand the Development node, it will automatically start.

trans-unit.source: This can take several seconds.
trans-unit.target: This can take several seconds.

trans-unit.source: You can continue to work in other areas of Visual Studio while the storage emulator starts.
trans-unit.target: You can continue to work in other areas of Visual Studio while the storage emulator starts.

trans-unit.source: To view resources in a storage account, expand the storage account’s node in Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: To view resources in a storage account, expand the storage account’s node in Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: The following sub-nodes appear:
trans-unit.target: The following sub-nodes appear:

trans-unit.source: Blobs
trans-unit.target: Blobs

trans-unit.source: Queues
trans-unit.target: Queues

trans-unit.source: Tables
trans-unit.target: Tables

trans-unit.source: The Blobs node displays a list of containers for the selected storage account.
trans-unit.target: The Blobs node displays a list of containers for the selected storage account.

trans-unit.source: Blob containers contain blob files, and you can organize these blobs into folders and subfolders.
trans-unit.target: Blob containers contain blob files, and you can organize these blobs into folders and subfolders.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>How to use Blob Storage from .NET</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>How to use Blob Storage from .NET</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for the Blobs node, and then choose Create Blob Container.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for the Blobs node, and then choose Create Blob Container.

trans-unit.source: Enter the name of the new container in the Create Blob Container dialog box and then choose Ok.
trans-unit.target: Enter the name of the new container in the Create Blob Container dialog box and then choose Ok.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Adding a new blob container</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Adding a new blob container</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The blob container name must begin with a number (0-9) or lowercase letter (a-z).
trans-unit.target: The blob container name must begin with a number (0-9) or lowercase letter (a-z).

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for the blob container you want to remove and then choose Delete.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for the blob container you want to remove and then choose Delete.

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for a blob container name in the list and then choose View Blob Container.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for a blob container name in the list and then choose View Blob Container.

trans-unit.source: When you view the contents of a blob container, it appears in a tab known as the blob container view.
trans-unit.target: When you view the contents of a blob container, it appears in a tab known as the blob container view.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VST_SE_BlobDesigner</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VST_SE_BlobDesigner</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can perform the following operations on blobs by using the buttons in the top-right corner of the blob container view:
trans-unit.target: You can perform the following operations on blobs by using the buttons in the top-right corner of the blob container view:

trans-unit.source: Enter a filter value and apply it
trans-unit.target: Enter a filter value and apply it

trans-unit.source: Refresh the list of blobs in the container
trans-unit.target: Refresh the list of blobs in the container

trans-unit.source: Upload a file
trans-unit.target: Upload a file

trans-unit.source: Delete a blob
trans-unit.target: Delete a blob

trans-unit.source: Deleting a file from a blob container doesn’t delete the underlying file; it only removes it from the blob container.
trans-unit.target: Deleting a file from a blob container doesn’t delete the underlying file; it only removes it from the blob container.

trans-unit.source: Open a blob
trans-unit.target: Open a blob

trans-unit.source: Save a blob to the local computer
trans-unit.target: Save a blob to the local computer

trans-unit.source: Choose the blob container in Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Choose the blob container in Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: In the container window, choose the Upload Blob button.
trans-unit.target: In the container window, choose the Upload Blob button.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Uploading a file into a blob folder</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Uploading a file into a blob folder</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Upload New File dialog box, choose the Browse button to specify the file you want to upload, and then enter a folder name in the Folder (optional) box.
trans-unit.target: In the Upload New File dialog box, choose the Browse button to specify the file you want to upload, and then enter a folder name in the Folder (optional) box.

trans-unit.source: You can add subfolders in container folders by following the same procedure.
trans-unit.target: You can add subfolders in container folders by following the same procedure.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t specify a folder name, the file will be uploaded to the top level of the blob container.The file appears in the specified folder in the container.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t specify a folder name, the file will be uploaded to the top level of the blob container.The file appears in the specified folder in the container.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Folder added to a blob container</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Folder added to a blob container</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Double-click the folder or press ENTER to see the contents of the folder.
trans-unit.target: Double-click the folder or press ENTER to see the contents of the folder.

trans-unit.source: When you’re in the container’s folder, you can navigate back to the root of the container by choosing the Open Parent Directory (up arrow) button.
trans-unit.target: When you’re in the container’s folder, you can navigate back to the root of the container by choosing the Open Parent Directory (up arrow) button.

trans-unit.source: Delete all of the files in the folder
trans-unit.target: Delete all of the files in the folder

trans-unit.source: Because folders in blob containers are virtual folders, you can’t create an empty folder, nor can you delete a folder to delete its file contents.
trans-unit.target: Because folders in blob containers are virtual folders, you can’t create an empty folder, nor can you delete a folder to delete its file contents.

trans-unit.source: You have to delete the entire contents of a folder to delete the folder.
trans-unit.target: You have to delete the entire contents of a folder to delete the folder.

trans-unit.source: You can filter the blobs that are displayed by specifying a common prefix.
trans-unit.target: You can filter the blobs that are displayed by specifying a common prefix.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you enter the prefix hello in the filter text box and then choose the Execute (!)button, only blobs that begin with 'hello' appear.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you enter the prefix hello in the filter text box and then choose the Execute (!)button, only blobs that begin with 'hello' appear.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VST_SE_FilterBlobs</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VST_SE_FilterBlobs</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The filter field is case-sensitive and doesn’t support filtering with wildcard characters.
trans-unit.target: The filter field is case-sensitive and doesn’t support filtering with wildcard characters.

trans-unit.source: Blobs can only be filtered by prefix.
trans-unit.target: Blobs can only be filtered by prefix.

trans-unit.source: The prefix may include a delimiter if you are using a delimiter to organize blobs in a virtual hierarchy.
trans-unit.target: The prefix may include a delimiter if you are using a delimiter to organize blobs in a virtual hierarchy.

trans-unit.source: For example, filtering on the prefix HelloFabric/ returns all blobs beginning with that string.
trans-unit.target: For example, filtering on the prefix HelloFabric/ returns all blobs beginning with that string.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, open the shortcut menu for one or more blobs and then choose Open, or choose the blob name and then choose the Open button, or double-click the blob name.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, open the shortcut menu for one or more blobs and then choose Open, or choose the blob name and then choose the Open button, or double-click the blob name.

trans-unit.source: The progress of a blob download appears in the Azure Activity Log window.
trans-unit.target: The progress of a blob download appears in the Azure Activity Log window.

trans-unit.source: The blob opens in the default editor for that file type.
trans-unit.target: The blob opens in the default editor for that file type.

trans-unit.source: If the operating system recognizes the file type, the file opens in a locally installed application; otherwise, you're prompted to choose an application that’s appropriate for the file type of the blob.
trans-unit.target: If the operating system recognizes the file type, the file opens in a locally installed application; otherwise, you're prompted to choose an application that’s appropriate for the file type of the blob.

trans-unit.source: The local file that’s created when you download a blob is marked as read-only.
trans-unit.target: The local file that’s created when you download a blob is marked as read-only.

trans-unit.source: Blob data is cached locally and checked against the blob's last modified time in the Blob service.
trans-unit.target: Blob data is cached locally and checked against the blob's last modified time in the Blob service.

trans-unit.source: If the blob has been updated since it was last downloaded, it will be downloaded again; otherwise the blob will be loaded from the local disk.
trans-unit.target: If the blob has been updated since it was last downloaded, it will be downloaded again; otherwise the blob will be loaded from the local disk.

trans-unit.source: By default a blob is downloaded to a temporary directory.
trans-unit.target: By default a blob is downloaded to a temporary directory.

trans-unit.source: To download blobs to a specific directory, open the shortcut menu for the selected blob names and choose Save As.
trans-unit.target: To download blobs to a specific directory, open the shortcut menu for the selected blob names and choose Save As.

trans-unit.source: When you save a blob in this manner, the blob file is not opened, and the local file is created with read-write attributes.
trans-unit.target: When you save a blob in this manner, the blob file is not opened, and the local file is created with read-write attributes.

trans-unit.source: Choose the Upload Blob button when the container is open for viewing in the blob container view.
trans-unit.target: Choose the Upload Blob button when the container is open for viewing in the blob container view.

trans-unit.source: You can choose one or more files to upload, and you can upload files of any type.
trans-unit.target: You can choose one or more files to upload, and you can upload files of any type.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Activity Log shows the progress of the upload.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Activity Log shows the progress of the upload.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to work with blob data, see <linkText>How to use the Azure Blob Storage Service in .NET</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to work with blob data, see <linkText>How to use the Azure Blob Storage Service in .NET</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Azure Diagnostics to log data from your Azure application and you have transferred logs to your storage account, you’ll see containers that were created by Azure for these logs.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Azure Diagnostics to log data from your Azure application and you have transferred logs to your storage account, you’ll see containers that were created by Azure for these logs.

trans-unit.source: Viewing these logs in Server Explorer is an easy way to identify problems with your application, especially if it’s been deployed to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Viewing these logs in Server Explorer is an easy way to identify problems with your application, especially if it’s been deployed to Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure Diagnostics, see <linkText>Collect Logging Data by Using Azure Diagnostics</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure Diagnostics, see <linkText>Collect Logging Data by Using Azure Diagnostics</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Open the blob’s shortcut menu and then choose Copy URL.
trans-unit.target: Open the blob’s shortcut menu and then choose Copy URL.

trans-unit.source: Select the blob and then choose the Open Blob button.
trans-unit.target: Select the blob and then choose the Open Blob button.

trans-unit.source: The file is downloaded to a temporary location and opened on the local computer.
trans-unit.target: The file is downloaded to a temporary location and opened on the local computer.

trans-unit.source: You must upload the blob again after you make changes.
trans-unit.target: You must upload the blob again after you make changes.

trans-unit.source: Storage services queues are hosted in an Azure storage account and you can use them to allow your cloud service roles to communicate with each other and with other services by a message passing mechanism.
trans-unit.target: Storage services queues are hosted in an Azure storage account and you can use them to allow your cloud service roles to communicate with each other and with other services by a message passing mechanism.

trans-unit.source: You can access the queue programmatically through a cloud service and over a web service for external clients.
trans-unit.target: You can access the queue programmatically through a cloud service and over a web service for external clients.

trans-unit.source: You can also access the queue directly by using Server Explorer in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: You can also access the queue directly by using Server Explorer in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: When you develop a cloud service that uses queues, you might want to use Visual Studio to create queues and work with them interactively while you develop and test your code.
trans-unit.target: When you develop a cloud service that uses queues, you might want to use Visual Studio to create queues and work with them interactively while you develop and test your code.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, you can view the queues in a storage account, create and delete queues, open a queue to view its messages, and add messages to a queue.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, you can view the queues in a storage account, create and delete queues, open a queue to view its messages, and add messages to a queue.

trans-unit.source: When you open a queue for viewing, you can view the individual messages, and you can perform the following actions on the queue by using the buttons in the top-left corner:
trans-unit.target: When you open a queue for viewing, you can view the individual messages, and you can perform the following actions on the queue by using the buttons in the top-left corner:

trans-unit.source: Refresh the view of the queue
trans-unit.target: Refresh the view of the queue

trans-unit.source: Add a message to the queue
trans-unit.target: Add a message to the queue

trans-unit.source: Dequeue the topmost message.
trans-unit.target: Dequeue the topmost message.

trans-unit.source: Clear the entire queue
trans-unit.target: Clear the entire queue

trans-unit.source: The following image shows a queue that contains two messages.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows a queue that contains two messages.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Viewing a Queue</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Viewing a Queue</linkText>

trans-unit.source: For more information about storage services queues, see <linkText>How to: Use the Queue Storage Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about storage services queues, see <linkText>How to: Use the Queue Storage Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For information about the web service for storage services queues, see <linkText>Queue Service Concepts</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about the web service for storage services queues, see <linkText>Queue Service Concepts</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to send messages to a storage services queue by using Visual Studio, see <linkText>Sending Messages to a Storage Services Queue</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to send messages to a storage services queue by using Visual Studio, see <linkText>Sending Messages to a Storage Services Queue</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Storage services queues are distinct from service bus queues.
trans-unit.target: Storage services queues are distinct from service bus queues.

trans-unit.source: For more information about service bus queues, see Service Bus Queues, Topics, and Subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: For more information about service bus queues, see Service Bus Queues, Topics, and Subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Table storage service stores large amounts of structured data.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Table storage service stores large amounts of structured data.

trans-unit.source: The service is a NoSQL datastore which accepts authenticated calls from inside and outside the Azure cloud.
trans-unit.target: The service is a NoSQL datastore which accepts authenticated calls from inside and outside the Azure cloud.

trans-unit.source: Azure tables are ideal for storing structured, non-relational data.
trans-unit.target: Azure tables are ideal for storing structured, non-relational data.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, select the Tables node of the storage account, and then choose Create Table.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, select the Tables node of the storage account, and then choose Create Table.

trans-unit.source: In the Create Table dialog box, enter a name for the table.
trans-unit.target: In the Create Table dialog box, enter a name for the table.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, open the Azure node, and then open the Storage node.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, open the Azure node, and then open the Storage node.

trans-unit.source: Open the storage account node that you are interested in, and then open the Tables node to see a list of tables for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Open the storage account node that you are interested in, and then open the Tables node to see a list of tables for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for a table and then choose View Table.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for a table and then choose View Table.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>An Azure table in Solution Explorer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>An Azure table in Solution Explorer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The table is organized by entities (shown in rows) and properties (shown in columns).
trans-unit.target: The table is organized by entities (shown in rows) and properties (shown in columns).

trans-unit.source: For example, the following illustration shows entities listed in the Table Designer:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following illustration shows entities listed in the Table Designer:

trans-unit.source: In the Table Designer, open the shortcut menu for an entity (a single row) or a property (a single cell) and then choose Edit.
trans-unit.target: In the Table Designer, open the shortcut menu for an entity (a single row) or a property (a single cell) and then choose Edit.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add or Edit a Table Entity</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add or Edit a Table Entity</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Entities in a single table aren’t required to have the same set of properties (columns).
trans-unit.target: Entities in a single table aren’t required to have the same set of properties (columns).

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind the following restrictions on viewing and editing table data.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind the following restrictions on viewing and editing table data.

trans-unit.source: You can’t view or edit binary data (type byte[]), but you can store it in a table.
trans-unit.target: You can’t view or edit binary data (type byte[]), but you can store it in a table.

trans-unit.source: You can’t edit the PartitionKey or RowKey values, because table storage in Azure doesn't support that operation.
trans-unit.target: You can’t edit the PartitionKey or RowKey values, because table storage in Azure doesn't support that operation.

trans-unit.source: You can’t create a property called Timestamp, Azure Storage services use a property with that name.
trans-unit.target: You can’t create a property called Timestamp, Azure Storage services use a property with that name.

trans-unit.source: If you enter a DateTime value, you must follow a format that's appropriate to the region and language settings of your computer (for example, MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS [AM|PM] for U.S. English).
trans-unit.target: If you enter a DateTime value, you must follow a format that's appropriate to the region and language settings of your computer (for example, MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS [AM|PM] for U.S. English).

trans-unit.source: In the Table Designer, choose the Add Entity button, which is near the top-right corner of the table view.
trans-unit.target: In the Table Designer, choose the Add Entity button, which is near the top-right corner of the table view.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add Entity</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add Entity</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Add Entity dialog box, enter the values of the PartitionKey and RowKey properties.
trans-unit.target: In the Add Entity dialog box, enter the values of the PartitionKey and RowKey properties.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add Entity Dialog Box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add Entity Dialog Box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Enter the values carefully because you can't change them after you close the dialog box unless you delete the entity and add it again.
trans-unit.target: Enter the values carefully because you can't change them after you close the dialog box unless you delete the entity and add it again.

trans-unit.source: You can customize the set of entities that appear in a table if you use the query builder.
trans-unit.target: You can customize the set of entities that appear in a table if you use the query builder.

trans-unit.source: To open the query builder, open a table for viewing.
trans-unit.target: To open the query builder, open a table for viewing.

trans-unit.source: Choose the rightmost button on the table view’s toolbar.
trans-unit.target: Choose the rightmost button on the table view’s toolbar.

trans-unit.source: The Query Builder dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The Query Builder dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: The following illustration shows a query that's being built in the query builder.
trans-unit.target: The following illustration shows a query that's being built in the query builder.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Query Builder</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Query Builder</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When you’re done building the query, close the dialog box.
trans-unit.target: When you’re done building the query, close the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: The resulting text form of the query appears in a text box as a WCF Data Services filter.
trans-unit.target: The resulting text form of the query appears in a text box as a WCF Data Services filter.

trans-unit.source: To run the query, choose the green triangle icon.
trans-unit.target: To run the query, choose the green triangle icon.

trans-unit.source: You can also filter entity data that appears in the Table Designer if you enter a WCF Data Services filter string directly in the filter field.
trans-unit.target: You can also filter entity data that appears in the Table Designer if you enter a WCF Data Services filter string directly in the filter field.

trans-unit.source: This kind of string is similar to a SQL WHERE clause but is sent to the server as an HTTP request.
trans-unit.target: This kind of string is similar to a SQL WHERE clause but is sent to the server as an HTTP request.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to construct filter strings, see <linkText>Constructing Filter Strings for the Table Designer</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to construct filter strings, see <linkText>Constructing Filter Strings for the Table Designer</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The following illustration shows an example of a valid filter string:
trans-unit.target: The following illustration shows an example of a valid filter string:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VST_SE_TableFilter</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VST_SE_TableFilter</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When Server Explorer connects to or gets data from a storage account, it might take up to a minute for the operation to complete.
trans-unit.target: When Server Explorer connects to or gets data from a storage account, it might take up to a minute for the operation to complete.

trans-unit.source: If it can’t connect, the operation might time out.
trans-unit.target: If it can’t connect, the operation might time out.

trans-unit.source: While data is retrieved, you can continue to work in other parts of Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: While data is retrieved, you can continue to work in other parts of Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: To cancel the operation if it’s taking too long, choose the Stop Refresh button on the Server Explorer toolbar.
trans-unit.target: To cancel the operation if it’s taking too long, choose the Stop Refresh button on the Server Explorer toolbar.

trans-unit.source: Select the Blobs node beneath Storage and choose the Refresh button on the Server Explorer toolbar.
trans-unit.target: Select the Blobs node beneath Storage and choose the Refresh button on the Server Explorer toolbar.

trans-unit.source: To refresh the list of blobs that is displayed, choose the Execute button.
trans-unit.target: To refresh the list of blobs that is displayed, choose the Execute button.

trans-unit.source: Select the Tables node beneath Storage and choose the Refresh button.
trans-unit.target: Select the Tables node beneath Storage and choose the Refresh button.

trans-unit.source: To refresh the list of entities that is displayed in the Table Designer, choose the Execute button on the Table Designer.
trans-unit.target: To refresh the list of entities that is displayed in the Table Designer, choose the Execute button on the Table Designer.

trans-unit.source: Select the Queues node, and then choose the Refresh button.
trans-unit.target: Select the Queues node, and then choose the Refresh button.

trans-unit.source: Choose the account name, and then choose the Refresh button on the toolbar for Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Choose the account name, and then choose the Refresh button on the toolbar for Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: There are two ways to add storage accounts by using Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: There are two ways to add storage accounts by using Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: You can create a new storage account in your Azure subscription, or you can attach an existing storage account.
trans-unit.target: You can create a new storage account in your Azure subscription, or you can attach an existing storage account.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the Storage node, and then choose Create Storage Account.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the Storage node, and then choose Create Storage Account.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a new Azure storage account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a new Azure storage account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select or enter the following information for the new storage account in the Create Storage Account dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Select or enter the following information for the new storage account in the Create Storage Account dialog box.

trans-unit.source: The Azure subscription to which you want to add the storage account.
trans-unit.target: The Azure subscription to which you want to add the storage account.

trans-unit.source: The name you want to use for the new storage account.
trans-unit.target: The name you want to use for the new storage account.

trans-unit.source: The region or affinity group (such as West US or East Asia).
trans-unit.target: The region or affinity group (such as West US or East Asia).

trans-unit.source: The type of replication you want to use for the storage account, such as Geo-Redundant.
trans-unit.target: The type of replication you want to use for the storage account, such as Geo-Redundant.

trans-unit.source: Choose Create.
trans-unit.target: Choose Create.

trans-unit.source: The new storage account appears in the Storage list in Solution Explorer.
trans-unit.target: The new storage account appears in the Storage list in Solution Explorer.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the Azure storage node, and then choose Attach External Storage.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the Azure storage node, and then choose Attach External Storage.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Adding an existing storage account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Adding an existing storage account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select or enter the following information for the new storage account in the Create Storage Account dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Select or enter the following information for the new storage account in the Create Storage Account dialog box.

trans-unit.source: The name of the existing storage account you want to attach.
trans-unit.target: The name of the existing storage account you want to attach.

trans-unit.source: You can enter a name or select it from the list.
trans-unit.target: You can enter a name or select it from the list.

trans-unit.source: The key for the selected storage account.
trans-unit.target: The key for the selected storage account.

trans-unit.source: This value is typically provided for you when you select a storage account.
trans-unit.target: This value is typically provided for you when you select a storage account.

trans-unit.source: If you want Visual Studio to remember the storage account key, select the Remember account key box.
trans-unit.target: If you want Visual Studio to remember the storage account key, select the Remember account key box.

trans-unit.source: The protocol to use to connect to the storage account, such as HTTP, HTTPS, or a custom endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The protocol to use to connect to the storage account, such as HTTP, HTTPS, or a custom endpoint.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>How to Configure Connection Strings</linkText><title></title> for more information about custom endpoints.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>How to Configure Connection Strings</linkText><title></title> for more information about custom endpoints.

trans-unit.source: If you created a storage account using the Read-Access Geo Redundant replication option, you can view its secondary endpoints.
trans-unit.target: If you created a storage account using the Read-Access Geo Redundant replication option, you can view its secondary endpoints.

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for the account name, and then choose Properties.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for the account name, and then choose Properties.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Storage secondary endpoints</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Storage secondary endpoints</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the account name, and then choose Delete.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the account name, and then choose Delete.

trans-unit.source: If you delete a storage account, any saved key information for that account is also removed.
trans-unit.target: If you delete a storage account, any saved key information for that account is also removed.

trans-unit.source: If you delete a storage account from Server Explorer, it doesn’t affect your storage account or any data that it contains; it simply removes the reference from Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: If you delete a storage account from Server Explorer, it doesn’t affect your storage account or any data that it contains; it simply removes the reference from Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: To permanently delete a storage account, use the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: To permanently delete a storage account, use the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Accessing the Azure Storage Services</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Accessing the Azure Storage Services</linkText><title></title>
